title: No light at polling booth:Voting In Pune's Polling Booth Took Place In Candlelight, Because There Was No Electricity
text:
Voting In The Dark: Polling Booth In Pune Had No Electricity, So People Had To Vote In Candlelight

Voting In The Dark: Polling Booth In Pune Had No Electricity, So People Had To Vote In Candlelight

Usually, before voting of any kind commences, various parties and leaders make tall promises about making basic amenities better and providing more infrastructure. Whether or not they actually follow through with these promises, is a different matter altogether. However, in Pune, the promises fell flat even before people could vote.

Voting in Maharashtra is taking place, and despite heavy rains people are coming to vote. However, in this polling booth, rain is not the problem, but electricity is! Unavailability of electricity forced people in Pune's Shivaji Nagar to vote in candlelight.

"The electricity supply is not there at this school. The problem was found in an electricity meter. Till now, it has not been resolved. Meanwhile, a generator is being provided by Election Commission. Voting is underway. There is no problem in that," Sanjay Padhtare, Sector Officer, told ANI.

ANI

Polling officials had candles on their tables which helped them tally voter details properly. Padhtare also said that 8 polling stations were affected by the unavailability of electricity. There were 96,661 polling booths in Maharashtra for citizens to cast their vote.

Don't Miss 3.1 K SHARES

Members of the transgender community also cast their vote at the Mahatma Gandhi Vidyalaya polling centre in Ichalkaranji constituency. The constituency has 56 voters belonging to the transgender community.

In Maharashtra, there was 43.77% voter turnout till 4:00 pm. Polling for 288 constituencies of Maharashtra began at 7:00 am and will continue till 6:00 pm in the evening.

Inputs From ANI
description: Voting in Maharashtra is taking place and despite heavy rains people are coming to vote. However, in this polling booth, rains are not the problem but electricity is! As unavailability of electricity forced people in Pune's Shivaji Nagar to vote in candlelight.
